Graphical abstract Mesoporous tin phosphate (M-SnPO) with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity was developed as a novel heterogeneous catalyst for fast and effective cascade conversion of bio-based citral to p-cymene. Image, graphical abstract Effective synthesis of aromatic compounds from renewable biomass is highly important yet challenging. p-Cymene is an attractive aromatic compound with various promising applications in the manufacture of fine chemicals. In this study, a novel and effective catalytic system based on mesoporous tin phosphate (M-SnPO) with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity was developed for the fast synthesis of p-cymene from the cyclodehydration of bio-based citral. Up to 78.5% yield of p-cymene was achieved from the cyclodehydration of citral at 180 °C within only 0.5 h, superior to the results reported for benchmark homogeneous acid catalysts. Characterization of as-prepared M-SnPO catalyst via various techniques indicates that the synergic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites, large pore-sized structure, and high surface area are responsible for its remarkable catalytic performance. In addition, the effectiveness of the M-SnPO catalyst could be almost sustained over multiple cycles without significant loss. The work herein is the first example of developing a Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic heterogeneous catalyst for the fast synthesis of p-cymene from the cyclodehydration of citral. Keywords P-Cymene Cyclodehydration Citral Heterogeneous catalysis Biomass conversion 1 Introduction Aromatic compounds are a pivotal class of feedstocks for the chemical industry in the manufacture of various commodity chemicals, such as pharmaceuticals, polymers, plastics, and agrochemicals [1-3]. And the demand for aromatic compounds is increasingly growing with the development of society [4]. The majority of aromatic compounds are currently accessible from nonrenewable fossil-based resources via catalytic cracking and reforming procedures [5]. To meet the requirements of socially sustainable development in conjunction with alleviating excessive dependence on fossil-based resources, alternative routes towards the production of aromatic compounds from renewable biomass have been exploited thanks to biomass featured with renewable, abundant, easily available, and carbon-rich properties [6-11]. Several elegant methods to aromatic compounds synthesis from biomass over the years have been developed, mainly including (i) depolymerization of lignin [12,13], (ii) catalytic fast pyrolysis of biomass [14,15], (iii) aromatization of biomass derivatives (e.g., gasification products and γ-valerolactone) [16,17], and (iv) sequential Diels-Alder reaction and dehydration of biomass-derived furan compounds with an alkene or its derivatives [18-21]. Despite the tremendous progress, particular interest is being placed on exploiting novel methodologies for the synthesis of aromatic compounds from biomass, attempting to improve the efficiency of biomass utilization, and synchronously accelerating the industrialization process for aromatic compounds synthesis from biomass [22,23]. Citral, as an important biomass-derived aldehyde, is abundant in bio-oils (e.g., lemongrass oil and Litsea cubeba oil) originated from biomass pyrolysis or accessible from biomass-derived terpenes and terpenoids [24-26]. Citral is an unsaturated aliphatic aldehyde with two kinds of unsaturated bonds (i.e., C = C and C = O) making it attractive as a building block for the production of fragrance, flavor, biofuels, pharmaceuticals, and agrochemicals [27-29]. Amongst, p-cymene is a representative derivative of citral via cyclodehydration, which possesses various applications such as the use as a solvent for the organic reaction [30], synthesis of terephthalic acid [31], as a versatile raw material for the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, herbicides, p-cresol and musk perfumes (Fig. 1 ) [32,33]. Although the synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration is early reported, only a few reports are available on this transformation due to its challenges, whilst research interest for this reaction is mainly concentrated on adopting homogeneous acid catalysts (e.g., hydrochloric acid and p-benzenesulfonic acid) (Scheme 1) [34-36]. As far as we know, only one heterogeneous catalyst comprising Rh nanoparticles immobilized by 1-n‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate (Rh-PF6) and the imidazolium-based ionic liquid was to date reported for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene, giving rise to 39.5% yield under a helium flow (20 mL/min) [37]. The corrosive of homogeneous acid catalysts and moderate activity of expensive Rh-PF6 catalyst limit their large-scale application. Undoubtedly, the development of a novel catalytic system based on an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene is highly necessary. Previous findings indicate that the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene is a tandem reaction that possibly proceeds to comply with a cyclization-dehydration-isomerization sequence in the presence of Brønsted acidic sites, as illustrated in Scheme 1 [34-36]. Knowledge from literature manifests that the cyclization of unsaturated aliphatic aldehyde [38,39] and the isomerization of alkene [26,40] are preferably facilitated by Lewis acidic sites. Spurred by the observations, one single heterogeneous catalyst embracing Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic sites is envisioned to enable the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene to proceed successfully. Metal phosphates have been received considerable attention in the field of catalysis owing to the characteristics of Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity, well tunability in properties and structure as well as low cost [41-44]. In light of Sn4+ showing strong Lewis acidity [45] together with the hierarchically porous structure endowing facile active-site accessibility [46,47], mesoporous tin phosphate (containing both micropores and mesopores) with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity was herein prepared and developed successfully for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene with giving a 78.5% yield of p-cymene. To the best of our knowledge, the approach of employing a heterogeneous catalyst with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity to facilitate the fast synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration has not been reported so far. This work is thus expected to provide more directions for the sustainable synthesis of aromatic compounds from biomass. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials SnCl4•5H2O (99.0%), hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB, 99%), naphthalene (99%), p-α-dimethylstyrene (>95.0%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Industrial Inc. p-Cymene (≥99.5%) was procured from Sigma-Aldrich. Citral (mixture of cis and trans, 95%) was provided by Alfa Aesar. H3PO4 (≥85%), n-heptane (≥98.5%), toluene (≥99.5%), acetonitrile (≥99.2%), 1,4-dioxane (99.5%), ethyl acetate (≥99.5%), and other reagents with analytically pure were bought from Chongqing Chuandong Chemical Reagent Company. 2.2 Preparation of catalytic materials Mesoporous tin phosphate was synthesized by a hydrothermal procedure associated with a template approach. Typically, 1.0 g of CTAB was dissolved in 25 mL deionized water with magnetic stirring (500 rpm) at 50 °C. 1.15 g (10 mmol) of H3PO4 was then introduced into the aqueous solution and the resultant mixture was allowed to stir for another 0.5 h at 50 °C. After cooling to room temperature, 10 mL of an aqueous solution containing 2.88 g (8 mmol) of SnCl4•5H2O was slowly added. Following stirring for 3 h at room temperature, the mixture was transferred into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave with Teflon lined and oven-heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Afterward, solid samples were collected by filtration, and then subjected to drying at 80 °C for 12 h followed by calcination in air at 550 °C for 6 h. The calcined material was denoted as M-SnPO. For comparison, common tin phosphate was fabricated with the above procedure but in the absence of CTAB, and the resulting material was designated C-SnPO. Besides, the bulk stannic oxide sample was also prepared by precipitation method using ammonium hydroxide as precipitating agent. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of as-prepared catalysts with a 2θ angle located between 5° and 90° were acquired on a D/max-TTR III diffractometer via using a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution of as-synthesized catalysts were determined based on N2 physisorption measurements, which were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument at −196 °C. Prior to the adsorption analysis, solid samples were evacuated at 200 °C for 4 h. Morphological and textural information of as-fabricated catalysts were collected by a field emission scanning electron microscopy (Nova NanoSEM 450 FEI microscope) and a Transmission electron microscopy (Tecnai G20 electron microscope). Aim at evaluating the acid amount of as-prepared catalysts, an AutoChem 2920 chemisorption analyzer with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was employed to acquire the NH3-TPD profiles of catalysts. Before the tests, the solid samples were preheated at 300 °C for 1 h in a helium flow (25 mL/min). After cooling down to 50 °C, the pure He gas was replaced by a mixture gas of NH3/He (v/v = 1/9), and the samples were subjected to the gas flow (25 mL/min) of NH3/He for 1 h. After removal of redundant and physically adsorbed NH3 gas by purging with pure He (25 mL/min, 1 h) and stabilization of the baseline, the temperature was raised to 700 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min and the amount of NH3 desorption was monitored by TCD. The nature of Brønsted and Lewis acidity was evaluated with IR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine, which was performed on a NICOLET iS50 (ThermoFisher Scientific) spectrometer equipped with a vacuum system and an MCT (mercury cadmium telluride) detector. The concentrations of Sn and P species in reaction filtrate after removing catalyst were evaluated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 720). 2.4 Catalytic evaluations and product analysis The catalytic tests of citral cyclodehydration were performed under autogenous pressure in a 25 mL stainless steel batch autoclave with magnetic stirring (500 rpm). Typically, the autoclave reactor was loaded with 0.152 g (1 mmol) of citral, 10 mL of n-heptane, 0.01 g of catalyst, and 0.04 g of naphthalene as an internal standard. After sealing, the autoclave was heated to a designed temperature (140, 160, 180, and 200 °C) to trigger the reaction. Zero time of the reaction was established once the autoclave temperature attained the set temperature occurring at 140, 160, 180, and 200 °C after 20, 24, 35, and 40 min, respectively. After the given reaction time (0.5–3.0 h), the autoclave was quickly immersed in a cooling water bath. Afterward, aliquots of reaction mixtures were sampled, filtered through a PTFE membrane (0.22 μm), and analyzed by GC–MS (Agilent 6890–5973) with an HP-5MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) and GC-FID (Agilent 7890B) with an HP-5 column (30 m × 0.320 mm × 0.25 μm). The reusability of M-SnPO was investigated by performing five catalytic consecutive runs under the reaction conditions of 180 °C and 0.5 h. The spent catalyst was collected via centrifugation after each run, washed with ethanol two times, and subsequently dried at 80 °C for 5 h. Prior to being reused for the subsequent successive run, the spent catalyst was regenerated by calcination at 550 °C for 2 h in air. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization As illustrated in Scheme 2, M-SnPO was fabricated through the hydrothermal method using CTAB as a template. The diffractograms of M-SnPO, C-SnPO, and SnO2 are exhibited in Fig. 2 a along with a representation of the tetragonal rutile SnO2 standard card (PDF#41–1445). A series of sharp diffraction peaks with high intensity at around 26.7°, 33.9°, and 51.9° were clearly observed for as-prepared SnO2, which well corresponded to (110), (101), and (211) planes of tetragonal rutile SnO2 [48, 49], respectively. In contrast, one broad diffraction peak with low intensity at 2θ ≈ 21° was found in the XRD pattern of M-SnPO, demonstrating the amorphous nature of the as-prepared M-SnPO, which also matched well with the previously reported results [43, 44]. Noteworthy, the diffraction peaks with low intensity indexed to (110), (101), and (211) planes of tetragonal rutile SnO2 were also visible in the XRD pattern of C-SnPO, implying the existence of a small amount of bulk stannic oxide in the as-prepared C-SnPO material. In addition, many other diffraction peaks were also clearly observed in the XRD pattern of C-SnPO, which were probably ascribed to lattice planes of cubic tin phosphate [50] and/or Sn(HPO4)2 [51]. Therefore, the results clearly implied the addition of CTAB during the preparation procedure could not only prevent the formation of the bulk stannic oxide but also ensure the generation of amorphous tin phosphate. The N2 physisorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions of as-prepared M-SnPO, C-SnPO, and SnO2 are presented in Fig. 2b and 2c, respectively. The physisorption isotherm of SnO2 falls within type-IV character showing a typical H5 hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of irregular mesopores derived from interparticle voids [52]. And the size of mesopores in SnO2 concentrated at around 7.2 nm, as shown in Fig. 2c. In the case of C-SnPO sample, a representative type-IV isotherm with a classical type-H3 hysteresis loop is presented, indicating the formation of slit-shaped mesopores due to the aggregation of C-SnPO particles [53]. The serious aggregation of particles can be finely validated by the SEM image of C-SnPO as shown in Figure S1. Besides, a broad pore size distribution is observed for C-SnPO (Fig. 2c), indicating the irregular nature of the formed slit-shaped mesopores. Nevertheless, the isotherm of M-SnPO shown in Fig. 2b is of type IV and the corresponding hysteresis loop is classified as type H4, which is characteristic of materials containing both microporosity and mesoporosity [54]. Moreover, a sharp capillary condensation step occurs at high relative pressures of 0.85–0.97 in the region of hysteresis, which is describable to the existence of large pore-sized mesoporous structure in M-SnPO sample [55]. Also, the presence of large pore-sized mesopores in M-SnPO can be further corroborated by its pore size distribution (Fig. 2c), wherein the pore sizes mainly concentrated at ∼1.6 and ∼23.8 nm. The large pore-sized mesopores within M-SnPO catalyst can improve the mass diffusion of substrates during the reaction and improve the exposure of active sites, which is favorable to improving its catalytic performance. As expected, the BET surface area of M-SnPO (323.3 m2/g) is larger than that of C-SnPO (21.0 m2/g) and SnO2 (28.0 m2/g). The SEM and TEM images of M-SnPO sample are depicted in Fig. 3 , and it can be found that the material is constituted of abundant small particles of 25–60 nm in diameter with irregular boundaries. The diameter of M-SnPO particles is smaller than that of C-SnPO particles and no obvious agglomeration of adjacent nanoparticles within M-SnPO is discovered compared to C-SnPO material (Figure S1), indicating the addition of CTAB during the synthesis process prevented the formation of large particles and agglomeration of adjacent nanoparticles. Moreover, the as-prepared M-SnPO material appears fluffy in appearance and abundant internal void space stemmed from the accumulation of nanoparticles is clearly observed in the SEM and TEM images (Fig. 3b and 3c), the results are consistent with the analysis of physisorption. In addition, the high-resolution TEM image of M-SnPO in Fig. 3d demonstrates that no lattice fringe is observed, which supports the amorphous nature of M-SnPO, also well agreeing with the results of XRD analysis. The NH3-TPD curves of SnO2, C-SnPO, and M-SnPO in Fig. 4 a show that a large desorption peak located in the range of 50 to 300 °C associating with weak acidity and a small desorption peak appeared in the range of 300–600 °C belonging to moderate acidity are observed for C-SnPO and M-SnPO, which is indicative of the presence of both weak and moderate acidic sites within the samples. In contrast, a small desorption peak occurred in the range of 50–300 °C and 300–600 °C is observed for SnO2, respectively, indicating the small amount of acid sites within SnO2. As expected, the largest amount of acidic sites among those as-prepared catalysts is observed for M-SnPO material (i.e., 2.29 mmol/g), resulting in M-SnPO material appearing as a promising acidic catalyst. The larger amount of acidic sites of M-SnPO material is mainly beneficial from its large pore-sized mesoporous structure along with large BET surface area, which permits M-SnPO material to afford more accessible active sites. Moreover, the identification of acidic properties for M-SnPO material was achieved by the pyridine-IR technique and the result is presented in Fig. 4b. The vibrations with strong intensity at 1455.7 and 1618.8 cm−1 assignable to Lewis acidity whilst the vibrations with low intensity at 1542.0 and 1637.5 cm−1 attributable to Brønsted acidity are clearly observed [56]. Furthermore, the vibration at 1490.8 cm−1 corresponding to the overlap of Brønsted and Lewis acidity is also appeared [57]. The above observations explicitly confirm the dual Lewis-Brønsted acidic nature of M-SnPO material, which contains a large amount of Lewis acidic sites along with a small amount of Brønsted acidic sites. Likewise, the C-SnPO catalyst also possessed dual Lewis-Brønsted acidic species, as evidenced by the pyridine-IR (Figure S2), in which the vibration at 1454.0 cm−1 is assigned to Lewis acid sites and the vibration at 1540.6 cm−1 belongs to Brønsted acid sites. 3.2 Cyclodehydration of citral to p-cymene over different catalysts Studies were commenced by scrutinizing the catalytic activity of as-prepared catalysts for the cyclodehydration of citral to p-cymene, attempting to identify an efficient catalyst that enables the fast synthesis of p-cymene from citral. Initial tests were performed under the conditions of 180 °C and 1 h in 10 mL of n-heptane using a catalyst loading of 0.01 g, and the results are compiled in Table 1 . Auto-cyclodehydration of citral in the absence of any catalyst almost afforded no p-cymene yield (entry 1, Table 1), underscoring the necessity of catalysts to facilitate the transformation. A low p-cymene yield of 2.0% with an inferior citral conversion of 37.6% was observed over SnO2 catalyst (entry 2, Table 1). It is speculated that the failure of the SnO2 catalyst is ascribed to the lack of Brønsted acidity. In contrast, the C-SnPO catalyst succeeded in facilitating the fast formation of p-cymene from citral under otherwise identical conditions due to its dual Lewis-Brønsted acidity (Figure S2), giving an appreciable p-cymene yield of 20.6% (entry 3, Table 1). The above results underscore the crucial role of dual Lewis-Brønsted acidity in the facile citral-to-p-cymene conversion. To our delight, M-SnPO catalyst exhibited a remarkable promotion for the fast synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration. With the as-prepared M-SnPO catalyst, an as high as 72.7% yield of p-cymene at 99.7% citral conversion was achieved within only 1 h at 180 °C. The excellent catalytic performance of M-SnPO was ascribed to a coalescence of its dual Lewis-Brønsted acidity and the large pore-sized mesoporous structure of catalyst along with large BET surface area which contributed to providing more accessible active sites and improving mass diffusion. On the other hand, the large pore-sized mesopores within M-SnPO catalyst can allow intermediate molecules to accommodate inside the pores, which further contributes to the excellent catalytic activity of M-SnPO catalyst. Comparison experiments were also performed by subjecting the precursors (i.e., SnCl4•5H2O and H3PO4) of SnPO material to catalyze the cyclodehydration of citral under otherwise identical conditions. Both SnCl4•5H2O and H3PO4, however, were found to be not enough efficient for the synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration, in spite of attaining high conversion of citral (entries 5 and 6, Table 1). The inferior catalytic behavior of SnCl4•5H2O and H3PO4 was attributed to the lack of Lewis acidity or enough Lewis acidic sites relative to M-SnPO catalyst, strongly underscoring the critical role of Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity for the cyclodehydration of citral to yield p-cymene. Noteworthy, piperitenol and p-menthatriene as intermediates with minor amounts and p-α-dimethylstyrene as a co-product with a yield of 1–11% were also detected throughout all the studies (Table 1 & Figure S3). Besides, those liquid chemicals in the reaction mixtures including target product, intermediates, and co-product were confirmed by GC–MS analysis as shown in Figure S4. Additionally, about 2∼4% yields of other unidentifiable by-products were observed during the reactions (Table 1). Clearly, evident carbon balance loss was observed in those reactions (Table 1), which was proposed to be a consequence of the formation of insoluble organic chemicals or carbon residue during the reactions. Building upon the above findings regarding the remarkable catalytic capability of M-SnPO catalyst for the fast cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene, M-SnPO catalyst was thus chosen for optimizing various reaction parameters attempting to achieve the optimum yield of p-cymene. 3.3 Reaction conditions optimization Effects of reaction temperature, reaction time, catalyst dosage and reaction solvent on the synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration over the M-SnPO catalyst were carefully scrutinized to determine the optimum reaction conditions. Firstly, the influences of reaction temperature and time on the catalytic performance of M-SnPO were investigated and the results are presented in Fig. 5 . It was found that complete conversion of citral were readily attained at reaction temperatures in the range of 140–200 °C with reaction times in the range of 0.5–3 h. Varying reaction temperatures was found to exert a profound effect on the yield of p-cymene, which was exemplified by the yield of p-cymene went up from 44.9% at 140 °C to 73.1% at 180 °C with a reaction time of 0.5 h (Fig. 5a & 5c). Whereas, the yield of p-cymene declined to 67.6% dramatically with the reaction temperature further rising to 200 °C (Fig. 5d), implying that higher temperature (i.e., 200 °C) went against the formation of p-cymene. An endeavor to enhance the yield of p-cymene by altering the reaction time at different reaction temperatures was proven to be unsuccessful (Fig. 5). In contrast, a slight decline was observed in p-cymene yield when the reaction time prolonged from 0.5 to 3.0 h in the range of 140–200 °C, suggesting that the M-SnPO catalyst succeeded in facilitating the fast synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration and long reaction time played a negative role in stabilizing the yield of p-cymene. Actually, a relatively high p-cymene yield was obtained after 10 min in the temperature range of 140–200 °C (Table S1), implying that the reaction had already started in the heating process. Then, the yield of p-cymene slowly increased with prolonging reaction time from 10 min to 30 min at different reaction temperatures (Table S1). Particularly, the p-cymene yields after 20 min at 180 and 200 °C were very close to that obtained at 30 min, further demonstrating that the synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehyration over M-SnPO catalyst was quite fast. In addition, reaction intermediates such as piperitenol and p-menthatriene were clearly detected as revealed by the GC–MS spectrum of the reaction mixture obtained at 140 °C (Figure S4). Especially, a minor amount (∼1.0% yield) of piperitenol in the reaction mixture was detected throughout the investigations, while considerable (7.0–20.0% yield) or trace amount (∼1.0% yield) of p-menthatriene was generated at low (e.g., 140 and 160 °C) or high (e.g., 180 & 200 °C) reaction temperatures, respectively. Besides, the amount of p-menthatriene in reaction mixtures decreased with the extension of reaction time, which could account for the p-menthatriene as an intermediate for p-cymene synthesis. Additionally, the formation of p-α-dimethylstyrene, as a co-product in the reaction, seemed to be insensitive to the reaction temperature, with yields varying in the range of 4.1–10.8% (Fig. 5). Hence, in terms of p-cymene yield, 180 °C and 0.5 h were screened to be optimum reaction temperature and time in the established catalytic system, respectively. Spurred by the above observations, the effect of M-SnPO catalyst dosage on the cyclodehydration of citral was studied to improve the p-cymene yield. The results in Fig. 6 a exhibited the yield of p-cymene presented an uptrend with the increment of catalyst dosage. The yield of p-cymene was only 35.2% with 0.005 g of M-SnPO catalyst, and enhanced sharply to 73.1% as the M-SnPO catalyst increased to 0.01 g, then escalated up to 78.5% gradually for 0.02 g of M-SnPO catalyst. The positive effect of M-SnPO catalyst dosage on the promotion of fast citral cyclodehydration was mainly beneficial from more exposed active sites together with higher exposure rates between active sites and substrate during the reaction originated from more amount of catalyst. Further increment of catalyst loading to 0.03 g, the promotion in raising p-cymene yield proved ineffective. In contrast, too much amount (i.e., 0.03 g) of M-SnPO catalyst was found deleterious for the formation of p-cymene with resulting in a slight drop in the p-cymene yield (Fig. 6a), which was probably caused by the excess catalyst incurring more side reactions during the reaction or strong catalyst adsorption effect towards organic chemicals. Nevertheless, the generation of p-α-dimethylstyrene was independent of catalyst loadings, with 3.5 to 7.1% yields in the reaction mixtures were observed. With an attempt to further improve the p-cymene yield, replacement of heptane with other organic solvents such as toluene, acetonitrile, 1,4-dioxane, and ethyl acetate for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene over M-SnPO were investigated under otherwise identical conditions. As depicted in Fig. 6b, high p-cymene yields (78.5% & 77.0%) were achieved in the solvents with low polarity (e.g., heptane and toluene), whereas moderate p-cymene yield (55.6%) corresponded to the solvent with moderate polarity (e.g., ethyl acetate) and low p-cymene yields (8.0% & 11.1%) were obtained in the solvents with high polarity (e.g., acetonitrile and 1,4-dioxane), firmly demonstrating that the solvent with high polarity was adverse to the synthesis of p-cymene from citral cyclodehydration. Those results in Fig. 6b pointed to a prominent influence of solvent on the p-cymene synthesis and decisively proved n-heptane as a promising solvent for the cyclodehydration of citral. 3.4 Reusability and stability of the catalyst Except for catalytic activity, for heterogeneous catalysts, reusability and stability are critical parameters for their prospective uses in industrial applications. The catalytic performance of M-SnPO for p-cymene synthesis in five consecutive runs under the optimum reaction conditions was herein surveyed in detail. Prior to re-use experiments, the spent M-SnPO catalyst was regenerated by calcination at 550 °C for subsequent each run, because of severe deactivation occurring if without heat treatment which resulted from the deposition of insoluble organic chemicals or carbon residue within the spent catalyst. The results in Fig. 7 a exhibited that the p-cymene yield decreased gradually in the five consecutive runs, but still preserved about 77.7% of its pristine catalytic performance at the fifth run in terms of p-cymene yield (61.0% yield), unequivocally demonstrating that M-SnPO catalyst was capable of re-utilizing and afforded acceptance catalytic performance in reuse experiments. Also, the above findings synchronously pointed out that the regeneration of the spent M-SnPO catalyst by calcination could not completely recover its pristine performance. In addition, both the concentrations of Sn and P species in the filtrate (after removal of the catalyst via filtration) were lower than 2 ppm as determined by ICP-OES analysis, clearly demonstrating that the leaching of active sites was negligible during the reaction. Thereupon regenerated catalyst was characterized by XRD, physisorptions, SEM, and NH3-TPD to determine the reason for slight deactivation. No crystallographic change is intuitively discovered by XRD analysis for regenerated catalyst compared to fresh one as described in Fig. 7b. Moreover, both micropores and mesopores were well-remained in the regenerated catalyst as revealed from the regenerated catalyst presenting the same type-IV isotherm and type-H4 hysteresis loop as fresh one (Fig. 7c). However, the BET surface area of the regenerated M-SnPO catalyst decreased by ∼29% (to 228.9 m2/g). The deposition of insoluble organic chemicals or carbon residue on the surface of regenerated catalyst resulting in the decreased surface area could be excluded due to the regenerated catalyst calcination at 550 °C in air, and thereby the declined BET surface area is possible ascribed to the aggregation of catalyst particles. Besides, the aggregation of particles within regenerated M-SnPO catalyst was further intuitively corroborated by SEM analysis (Figure S5), strongly confirming the declined surface area resulted from particle aggregation. Concomitantly, the acid amount of regenerated M-SnPO catalyst was dropped (to 1.93 mmol/g) in comparison with fresh catalyst (2.29 mmol/g) (Fig. 7d), which was caused by the decreased surface area. Retrospectively, the characterization studies clearly point out that the partial deactivation of regenerated catalyst originates from reduced accessibility of active sites owing to the decrease of surface area. In any case, the reusability investigations along with inspections of regenerated catalyst strongly demonstrate that the M-SnPO catalyst can be reutilized, and hence can serve as a potential candidate for the facile cyclodehydration of citral to p-cymene in industrial applications. 3.5 Plausible reaction pathway Previously studies gave some descriptions for the possible reaction pathway of the acid-catalyzed cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene [34-37]. It is hypothesized that the pathway of citral-to-p-cymene conversion catalyzed by Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic M-SnPO is analogous to that proposed for reported homogeneous acid catalysts. Based upon the above catalytic test along with knowledge from the literature [34-37, 38-40], a plausible reaction pathway for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene over Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic M-SnPO was proposed as illustrated in Scheme 3 . The reaction was initiated by the cyclization of citral over Lewis acidic sites to give piperitenol. The resulting piperitenol then underwent the dehydration in the presence of Brønsted acidic sites to afford p-menthatriene, which in turn underwent the isomerization promoted by Lewis acidic sites to yield p-cymene. In addition, the yield of p-menthatriene in reaction mixtures decreased with the extension of reaction time as shown in Fig. 5, substantiating the p-menthatriene to be an intermediate for the p-cymene synthesis, thus reinforcing the proposed tandem reaction pathway. Concurrently, the formed piperitenol originated from citral cyclodehydration could undergo hydration (water stemmed from the above-mentioned dehydration) to generate compound I (marked in Scheme 3) followed by the dehydration to produce compound II (marked in Scheme 3). Subsequently, the generated compound II went through allylic oxidation and/or disproportionation to furnish compound III (marked in Scheme 3), and then to p-α-dimethylstyrene through successive dehydration. Of note is that the reaction pathway involving hydration-dehydration-allylic oxidation/disproportionation for piperitenol was not dominant due to only a trace amount of water in the reaction mixture. Coincidently, minor yields of p-α-dimethylstyrene were always detected throughout the investigations, which corresponded well to the proposed inference, further confirming the proposed plausible reaction pathway. Particularly, compared with previous efforts depending on the usage of homogeneous acid catalysts (e.g., hydrochloric acid and p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate) for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene, the performance of M-SnPO catalyst with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity described herein surpasses previously reported results, or at least is comparable to that of benchmark homogeneous acid catalyst (pH=1.8) (Table 2 ). Moreover, M-SnPO catalyst provided the highest TOF value for the p-cymene synthesis from citral cyclodehydration, clearly demonstrating its superiority in catalytic performance. Furthermore, the M-SnPO catalyst developed herein however featured easy-handling and non-corrosive properties with ready recyclability and reusability, highlighting the superiority of the established catalytic system and exhibiting great potential for large-scale applications. To the best of our knowledge, the work presented herein is the first reported example of the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene with heterogeneous Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic catalyst and concurrently shows the best performance ever reported catalysts for citral-to-p-cymene transformation. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly effective strategy for the tandem synthesis of p-cymene from biomass-derived citral through sequential cyclization, dehydration, and isomerization was successfully realized by large pore-sized mesoporous tin phosphate catalyst with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity. Up to 78.5% yield of p-cymene was attained in heptane over M-SnPO catalyst at 180 °C with only 0.5 h, superior to the results reported for homogeneous acid catalysts (e.g., HCl). Characterization results in conjunction with analytic data finely demonstrated that the excellent catalytic performance of M-SnPO mainly stemmed from the synergistic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites as well as facile active-site accessibility and improved mass diffusion due to its large surface area and large pore-sized mesoporous structure. In addition, M-SnPO catalyst could be reused multiple cycles and preserved about 78% of the original catalytic activity of the fresh catalyst. Slight deactivation of catalyst was mainly associated with the aggregation of particles within used M-SnPO catalyst, resulting in reduced surface area and acid amount. Furthermore, a plausible reaction pathway for the cyclodehydration of citral into p-cymene over M-SnPO was proposed, and the as-prepared M-SnPO catalyst could serve as an attractive catalyst candidate for the practical synthesis of p-cymene from bio-based citral. The methodology described in this work offers a fast and sustainable route for the production of p-cymene, and also provides important clues for the sustainable synthesis of aromatic compounds from biomass. coredata.dc:description: Effective synthesis of aromatic compounds from renewable biomass is highly important yet challenging. p-Cymene is an attractive aromatic compound with various promising applications in the manufacture of fine chemicals. In this study, a novel and effective catalytic system based on mesoporous tin phosphate (M-SnPO) with Lewis-Brønsted dual acidity was developed for the fast synthesis of p-cymene from the cyclodehydration of bio-based citral. Up to 78.5% yield of p-cymene was achieved from the cyclodehydration of citral at 180 °C within only 0.5 h, superior to the results reported for benchmark homogeneous acid catalysts. Characterization of as-prepared M-SnPO catalyst via various techniques indicates that the synergic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites, large pore-sized structure, and high surface area are responsible for its remarkable catalytic performance. In addition, the effectiveness of the M-SnPO catalyst could be almost sustained over multiple cycles without significant loss. The work herein is the first example of developing a Lewis-Brønsted dual acidic heterogeneous catalyst for the fast synthesis of p-cymene from the cyclodehydration of citral.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous tin phosphate as an effective catalyst for fast cyclodehydration of bio-based citral into p-cymene
